study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal and child supplementation with SQ-LNS during the first 1,000 days influenced parental investments in health and human capital, including breastfeeding.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention generally did not affect parental investments in breastfeeding or other domains for the treated child or untreated siblings, suggesting no meaningful impact on parents' expectations or behaviors.
population_specificity: Mothers and children in Ghana participating in a randomized trial.
effective_dosage: Small-quantity lipid-based nutrient supplements (SQ-LNS), exact dosage not specified.
study_duration: Throughout much of the first 1,000 days (approximately 2.7 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of breastfeeding in mitigating adverse effects of maternal antibiotic use on the neonatal gut microbiome and immune system development.
results_summary: The abstract suggests breastfeeding is a therapeutic intervention that may help counteract the negative impacts of maternal antibiotic use on infant health outcomes like atopy, asthma, allergy, and obesity, though confounding variables limit definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Neonates and infants affected by maternal antibiotic use during pregnancy or delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the bioavailability and effects of the micronutrient supplement LaVita® on pregnancy-relevant parameters, including its safety and efficacy for postnatal breastfeeding.
results_summary: Regular intake of the supplement increased serum levels of the supplemented substances, significantly decreased homocysteine, and slightly lowered Hb-alpha-1c, indicating improved metabolic status. Female participants benefited more than males.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers, including a "male group control."

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify sialic acid levels in breast milk from HIV-positive Tanzanian mothers and assess the impact of maternal diet on these levels.
results_summary: Milk sialic acid levels were highest at 2 weeks postpartum (6.89 mmol/l) and declined by 3 months (2.49 mmol/l). No correlation was found between sialic acid levels and maternal diet, age, BMI, CD4+ count, or infant birth weight.
population_specificity: HIV-positive Tanzanian women during pregnancy and early lactation.
effective_dosage: Daily protein-calorie supplement and micronutrient supplement or micronutrient supplement only.
study_duration: Last trimester of pregnancy up to 6 months postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare breastfeeding rates between persistent smokers and non-smokers across two successive pregnancies.
results_summary: Persistent smokers had lower rates of breastfeeding in both pregnancies compared to persistent non-smokers (P < 0.001). The study did not evaluate breastfeeding efficacy or safety directly.
population_specificity: Women who delivered two successive singleton pregnancies between 2011-2015 at a large maternity hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of maternal calcium supplementation on bone loss during pregnancy and bone recovery postpartum in breastfeeding women.
results_summary: The calcium group showed significantly greater increases in radial total BMD and tibial cortical BMD at 12 months postpartum compared to the placebo group, suggesting improved bone recovery. Trabecular and total BMD at the tibia also trended toward higher values in the calcium group.
population_specificity: Pregnant women aged 19-50 years with typical US calcium intake.
study_duration: From 16 weeks of gestation until delivery

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of early-life probiotic exposure (L. rhamnosus HN001 and B. animalis subsp. lactis HN019) on infant gut microbiota development and eczema risk reduction.
results_summary: The study found a 50% reduced eczema risk in the HN001 probiotic group compared to placebo, with gut microbiota composition and functional capacity analyzed from birth to 2 years. No adverse effects or safety concerns related to breastfeeding were reported.
population_specificity: 474 infants from birth to 2 years, including mothers from 35 weeks gestation until 6 months post-partum if breastfeeding.
effective_dosage: L. rhamnosus HN001 (6×10^9 CFU/day) and B. animalis subsp. lactis HN019 (dosage not specified).
study_duration: Infants received probiotics from birth to 2 years; mothers from 35 weeks gestation until 6 months post-partum if breastfeeding.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of postnatal n-3 LC-PUFA supplementation (via fish oil) through lactation or complementary food on child development in rural Ethiopia.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of n-3 LC-PUFA supplementation on overall or social-emotional developmental performance in children aged 6-24 months. Developmental performance decreased over time regardless of intervention.
population_specificity: Rural Ethiopian mothers and infants aged 6-12 months at baseline.
effective_dosage: Maternal intervention: 215 mg DHA + 285 mg EPA daily; Child intervention: 169 mg DHA + 331 mg EPA daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early limited-volume pasteurized donor human milk (DHM) supplementation affects breastfeeding outcomes in healthy term newborns with ≥4.5% weight loss in the first 36 hours.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in formula use at 1 week (21% vs 7%) or in any breastfeeding (79% vs 90%) and breastfeeding without formula at 3 months (62% vs 77%) between DHM-supplemented and exclusively breastfed infants. Early DHM supplementation did not show a favorable impact on breastfeeding outcomes.
population_specificity: Healthy, term breastfeeding newborns with ≥4.5% weight loss in the first 36 hours.
effective_dosage: Early limited-volume DHM supplementation (exact dosage not specified).
study_duration: Follow-up surveys at 1 week, 1, 2, and 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effects of early childhood supplementation with Lactobacillus rhamnosus HN001 on allergic disease outcomes, including eczema, asthma, wheeze, hay fever, and atopic sensitization.
results_summary: Early HN001 supplementation significantly reduced the 12-month prevalence of eczema and hay fever at age 11, as well as lifetime prevalence of atopic sensitization, eczema, and wheeze. HN019 had no significant effects on these outcomes.
population_specificity: Children followed up to age 11 years in a two-center randomized placebo-controlled trial.
effective_dosage: 6 × 10^9 colony-forming units (CFU) per day (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether probiotic supplementation could counteract the negative effects of antibiotic use or caesarean birth on infant gut microbiota, particularly in breastfed infants.
results_summary: Probiotic supplementation significantly improved microbiota composition in breastfed infants, increasing bifidobacteria and reducing Proteobacteria and Clostridia, while mitigating the adverse effects of antibiotics and caesarean birth. The placebo group showed altered microbiota with reduced Bifidobacterium abundance due to these factors.
population_specificity: Infants born by caesarean section or receiving antibiotics, with a focus on breastfed infants.
effective_dosage: Bifidobacterium breve Bb99 (Bp99 2 × 10^8 CFU/day) and other probiotic strains (total 1 × 10^9 CFU/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health benefits of human milk oligosaccharides (HMOs) in preterm infants, focusing on gut adaptation and reducing necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) incidence.
results_summary: The study found that HMOs in breast milk serve as prebiotics and immunomodulators, but their effects on gut maturation and NEC prevention in preterm infants may depend on gut maturity. Supplemented HMOs showed limited efficacy in early weeks but may offer gut protection in later, more mature phases.
population_specificity: Preterm infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a protein-calorie supplement (PCS) plus a micronutrient supplement (MNS) improved outcomes for HIV-infected lactating women and their infants compared to MNS alone.
results_summary: The PCS + MNS intervention increased maternal energy and protein intake and infant birth weight but did not affect infant weight at 3 months or maternal BMI at 6 months. It also reduced infant HIV transmission compared to MNS alone.
population_specificity: Pregnant HIV-infected women in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, enrolled in PMTCT programs who intended to breastfeed for 6 months.
study_duration: From the third trimester of pregnancy through 6 months of breastfeeding.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop clinical protocols for managing common medical problems impacting breastfeeding success, free from commercial influence.
results_summary: The abstract states that the protocols serve as guidelines for breastfeeding care but do not establish exclusive treatment courses or medical care standards, allowing for individualized treatment variations.
population_specificity: Breastfeeding mothers and infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the conjugated linolenic acid (CLA) and vaccenic acid (VA) content in human breast milk from mothers with different diets and compare these levels with those in infant formulas (IF) and follow-up formulas (FF).
results_summary: The study found that breast milk from mothers consuming dairy products had significantly higher CLA (0.49%) and VA (0.69%) levels compared to those with dairy-deficient diets (CLA 0.27%, VA 0.36%). Infant formulas contained only trace amounts of these fatty acids, indicating a nutritional gap compared to breast milk.
population_specificity: Fifty healthy breastfeeding mothers, categorized into two groups based on dairy consumption (20 with low dairy, 30 with conventional diets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence and determinants of delayed breastfeeding, prelacteal food provision, and infant formula use in hospital settings.
results_summary: Only 32.2% of infants were breastfed within 1 hour of birth, with 40.8% receiving traditional prelacteal foods and 34.9% given formula. Cesarean delivery and lack of skin-to-skin contact were associated with delayed breastfeeding and increased formula use.
population_specificity: 700 women from three public and two private maternity hospitals in Shiraz, Iran.
study_duration: Data collected between June 2014 and March 2015 (hospital stay duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the dose-dependent effect of human milk fortifier (HMF) on the osmolality of preterm human milks (PHMs) under different gestational, lactation, storage, and treatment conditions.
results_summary: The study found that adding up to 4% (w/v) of HMF to PHM increased its nutritional quality and osmolality without exceeding 450 mOsm/kgH2O, regardless of milk origin, quality, or hospital practices.
population_specificity: Preterm infants born before 28 weeks or between 29-31 weeks of gestation, with mothers breastfeeding 1-4 weeks postpartum.
study_duration: Osmolality was measured at baseline and 24 hours after adding HMF.

study_goal: To determine whether probiotic supplementation (Lactobacillus rhamnosus HN001 or Bifidobacterium animalis subsp. lactis HN019) during early life improves neurocognitive outcomes at 11 years of age in children at risk of allergic disease.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in neurocognitive outcomes (intelligence, executive function, attention, depression, anxiety) between children who received probiotics (HN001 or HN019) and those who received a placebo. The authors concluded that these probiotics were not associated with neurocognitive benefits at 11 years but noted that other probiotics might still have potential effects.
population_specificity: Children born between March 2004 and August 2005, at risk of developing allergic disease, and their mothers (pregnant women).
effective_dosage: Mothers took probiotics or placebo daily from 35 weeks gestation until six months if breastfeeding; infants received the same treatment from birth to two years.
study_duration: From 35 weeks gestation until two years of age for infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of maternal milk supplementation (MMS) with breastfeeding support on breastfeeding practices and child neurodevelopment outcomes at 30 months old.
results_summary: The intervention group had longer exclusive breastfeeding duration, higher exclusive breastfeeding rates at 6 months, and lower risk of discontinuing exclusive breastfeeding compared to the control group. Children in the intervention group also showed significantly better cognitive and motor functions and a tendency toward improved social-emotional behavior.
population_specificity: 204 Vietnamese women and their offspring.
study_duration: From the last trimester to 12 weeks postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of milk supplementation and exposure to taste and smell with each feed on breastfeeding rates, growth, and developmental outcomes in moderate- to late-preterm infants.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding breastfeeding effects, as the trial is ongoing and outcomes such as breastfeeding rates are listed as secondary measures.
population_specificity: Moderate- to late-preterm infants (born between 32 weeks' gestation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the physical and emotional health benefits of breastfeeding for nursing mothers, which are often overlooked in literature.
results_summary: The study emphasizes the multiple benefits of breastfeeding for mothers, including physical and emotional health improvements, though specific results are not detailed in the abstract. The authors conducted a literature review using multiple databases to support their findings.
population_specificity: Nursing mothers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current knowledge on nutrient concentrations in human milk and how they are influenced by lactational stage, maternal factors, and supplementation.
results_summary: The study highlights the importance of exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months and discusses how maternal nutrition and supplementation can affect human milk quality. It also reviews trends in nutrient concentrations over lactation.
population_specificity: General breastfeeding mothers and infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze breast-milk vitamin B-12 concentrations and supplement use patterns among vegan, vegetarian, and nonvegetarian breastfeeding mothers.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in low vitamin B-12 prevalence among dietary groups, but individual vitamin B-12 supplement use was higher in vegans and positively predicted milk vitamin B-12 concentrations, while multivitamin use had a negative relation.
population_specificity: 74 breastfeeding mothers (26 vegan, 22 vegetarian, 26 nonvegetarian).
effective_dosage: Not specified (supplement doses mentioned as exceeding the Recommended Dietary Allowance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess adherence to infant feeding guidelines among very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) infants and explore sociodemographic factors influencing these practices.
results_summary: The study found low rates of partial and exclusive breastfeeding among VLBW infants up to 6 months corrected age, with only 12% adhering to all recommended feeding practices. Mothers with university degrees were more likely to provide mother's milk, while those of Middle Eastern/South Asian ethnicity were less likely.
population_specificity: Very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) infants (<1500 g) and their families.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between breastfeeding, gut microbiota, and the risk of overweight in infants, accounting for supplementary feeding types and timing.
results_summary: Exclusive breastfeeding at 3 months was associated with a lower risk of overweight compared to formula feeding, with gut microbiota differences partially explaining this effect. Formula supplementation altered microbiota composition but did not significantly impact overweight risk, while complementary foods without formula maintained microbiota profiles similar to exclusive breastfeeding.
population_specificity: 1087 infants from the prospective CHILD pregnancy cohort, recruited between 2009 and 2012.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how maternal vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy and lactation affects DNA methylation in mothers and breastfed infants.
results_summary: Maternal vitamin D supplementation altered DNA methylation patterns in both mothers and breastfed infants, with changes linked to cell migration, immune function, and metabolic processes. The study found significant methylation differences in intervention groups compared to controls.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their breastfed infants (4-6 weeks old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of breastfeeding in primary allergy prevention and compare it with other nutritional interventions and allergen introduction strategies.
results_summary: Breastfeeding is identified as a key pillar for primary allergy prevention, supported by its role in reducing food allergy risk. The study also highlights the shift from prolonged allergen avoidance to proactive allergen introduction from 4 months of age, with breastfeeding remaining a foundational strategy.
population_specificity: Infants and young children, particularly those at risk of food allergies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify protective factors for exclusive breastfeeding during the intrahospital period by analyzing systematic reviews.
results_summary: The study found six key protective factors for exclusive breastfeeding: early skin-to-skin contact, rooming-in care, intervention for painful nipples, restriction of infant supplementation, baby-led breastfeeding, and educational interventions for mothers. These measures were supported by evidence to encourage breastfeeding and prevent weaning during hospitalization.
population_specificity: Mothers and infants during the intrahospital period (excluding preterm infants and those with orofacial malformations).
study_duration: From delivery room to hospital discharge

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between breastfeeding and nutritional status, pulmonary outcomes, and acquisition of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in infants with cystic fibrosis.
results_summary: Breastfeeding for at least 3 months delayed the first acquisition of Pseudomonas aeruginosa, but feeding modalities (including breastfeeding) were not associated with nutritional status.
population_specificity: Infants with cystic fibrosis diagnosed by newborn screening and followed up to 24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the adequacy of oral vitamin K prophylaxis in preventing Vitamin K Deficiency Bleeding (VKDB) in exclusively breastfed infants.
results_summary: Despite oral vitamin K supplementation, the infant developed late-onset VKDB, suggesting current guidelines may need revision for dosage and timing standardization. Intravenous vitamin K administration led to complete recovery.
population_specificity: A 2-month and 20-day-old exclusively breastfed Caucasian male infant.
study_duration: From birth until presentation at 2 months and 20 days.

study_goal: To determine if supplementing breastfeeding with early limited formula (ELF) affects breastfeeding duration, readmission rates, and intestinal microbiota in newborns with significant weight loss.
results_summary: ELF did not interfere with breastfeeding rates at 1 month, showed no significant difference in breastfeeding without formula, and did not negatively impact intestinal microbiota. ELF may reduce readmission rates, though the difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Exclusively breastfeeding newborns (24-72 hours old) with weight loss ≥75th percentile and mothers without mature milk production.
effective_dosage: 10 mL formula after each breastfeeding, stopped at onset of copious maternal milk production.
study_duration: Until onset of copious maternal milk production (timing not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal vitamin D intake during breastfeeding, alongside infant supplementation, influences infants' vitamin D status.
results_summary: The study found that higher maternal vitamin D intake was associated with increased infant vitamin D levels, suggesting that both maternal intake and infant supplementation are necessary for optimal infant vitamin D status. Infants' median 25(OH)D was 96.0 nmol/L, with 25% below the optimal threshold of 75 nmol/L.
population_specificity: Breastfed infants from the APrON cohort, with 72% exclusively breastfed and 90% receiving vitamin D supplements.
effective_dosage: Median maternal vitamin D intake was 665 IU/day, with 25% below the recommended 400 IU/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether variations in maternal or infant diet, including breastfeeding, influence the risk of allergic or autoimmune disease in children.
results_summary: The study found weak support for breastfeeding promotion reducing the risk of eczema during infancy and an association between longer exclusive breastfeeding and reduced type 1 diabetes mellitus, though the certainty of these findings was low. No significant harmful effects of breastfeeding were reported.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, lactating mothers, and infants up to one year of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if probiotic exposure during breastfeeding influenced infant fecal microbiome composition and assessed associated changes in breast milk immunity and infant health.
results_summary: Probiotic exposure led to higher Bifidobacterium abundance in infants at week 1 but no lasting microbiome changes or altered breast milk immunity. Probiotic-supplemented infants showed higher fecal sIgA responses but also higher incidences of mucosal-associated illnesses later in life.
population_specificity: 86 breastfeeding mothers and their infants, with 35 mothers self-administering probiotics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare selenium levels and speciation in human breast milk versus formula-based animal milk, assessing the suitability of inorganic selenium supplementation in infant formula.
results_summary: The study found that human breast milk is the ideal source of selenium for infants, while formula-based alternatives often contain inorganic selenium (sodium selenite or selenate), which may not be optimal. Advances in speciation analysis suggest future improvements for selenium supplementation in infant formula.
population_specificity: Infants (general, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal probiotic supplementation alone (without infant supplementation) could reduce infant eczema, compared to a previous study where both mother and child received the probiotic.
results_summary: Maternal-only HN001 supplementation did not significantly reduce infant eczema, SCORAD ≥ 10, wheeze, or atopic sensitization by 12 months, contrasting with the previous study where combined mother-child supplementation showed significant reductions. HN001 was not detected in breastmilk, and breastmilk immune markers remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Mothers from 35 weeks of gestation until 6 months post-partum if breastfeeding, and their infants.
study_duration: From 35 weeks of gestation until 6 months post-partum if breastfeeding.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence supporting the use of a supplemental feeding tube device (SFTD) as a method of supplementation for breastfed infants.
results_summary: The study found very limited research on SFTDs but suggested they may be useful for supplementation. High-quality research is needed to assess their efficacy in supporting exclusive and overall breastfeeding rates.
population_specificity: Breastfed infants, including term and premature infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to map the range of ethical issues in nutrition-related public health interventions, including breastfeeding, and identify the contexts in which these issues arise.
results_summary: The study found that ethical issues in breastfeeding interventions are addressed less frequently compared to obesity and non-communicable diseases, highlighting the varied ethical challenges and contextual complexities in public health nutrition.
population_specificity: Not specified (general public health interventions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how the 2012 ACA policy change, which mandated coverage for lactation-support services and breastfeeding equipment, affected breastfeeding outcomes.
results_summary: The ACA policy change was associated with a 10% increase in breastfeeding duration and a 21% increase in exclusive breastfeeding duration, but no significant effects on breastfeeding initiation or age at first formula feeding.
population_specificity: Children aged 19 to 23 months covered by private health insurance or Medicaid in the US.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between maternal milk vitamin B-12 concentrations and infant serum vitamin B-12 levels, and identify factors linked to adequate infant vitamin B-12 status in an unsupplemented rural Kenyan population.
results_summary: The study found a positive correlation between maternal milk and infant serum vitamin B-12 levels, with maternal milk vitamin B-12 significantly associated with infant adequacy. Despite low maternal milk vitamin B-12 concentrations, infant deficiency prevalence was low, though one-third had depleted or deficient levels.
population_specificity: Unsupplemented mothers and infants (1-6 months postpartum) in rural western Kenya.

study_goal: To examine the effect of feeding type (mothers' own milk, donor human milk, formula) on microbial patterns in preterm infants and identify factors promoting beneficial bacterial colonization.
results_summary: Mothers' own breast milk increased gut microbial diversity and influenced community structure compared to donor milk or formula. Prebiotics and probiotics showed positive bifidogenic effects, though results varied.
population_specificity: Preterm infants, including extremely low birth weight (ELBW) and very low birth weight infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal breastfeeding is associated with a reduced risk of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in children.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that children with ASD were significantly less likely to have been breastfed than children without ASD (OR = 0.61, 95% CI = 0.45-0.83, P = 0.002). Subgroup analyses indicated that breastfeeding, including with additional supplements, may protect against ASD.
population_specificity: Children with and without autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of prebiotic supplementation (versus no prebiotics) on the development of allergic diseases in pregnant women, breastfeeding mothers, and infants.
results_summary: Prebiotic supplementation in infants showed potential reductions in eczema, wheezing/asthma, and food allergy risks, but the certainty of these estimates was very low due to bias and imprecision. No adverse effects were reported, and growth rate and final infant weight were minimally affected.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, breastfeeding mothers, and infants (though no studies were found for pregnant or breastfeeding women).

study_goal: To determine if maternal omega-3 LC-PUFA supplementation during late pregnancy and breastfeeding affects inflammatory cytokine levels in mothers and infants.
results_summary: Maternal omega-3 supplementation increased anti-inflammatory cytokines (IL-4, IL-10, IL-2) and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, TNF-α) in mothers and infants, suggesting a shift toward an anti-inflammatory environment.
population_specificity: 46 pregnant women and their infants.
effective_dosage: 400 mL/day of a fish oil-enriched dairy drink (320 mg DHA + 72 mg EPA).
study_duration: From week 28 of pregnancy until the fourth month of lactation.

study_goal: To investigate the prevalence of difficulties in initial breastfeeding techniques and their association with breast disorders in postpartum women.
results_summary: The study found that inadequate baby attachment (25%), baby response to breast contact (26.1%), and breast disorders (28.3%) were key difficulties. Adolescent mothers, low maternal schooling, and supplement provision were associated with higher odds of breast disorders, while working outside the household was protective.
population_specificity: 276 mother-baby pairs in rooming-in at 3 hospitals in Minas Gerais, Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and risks of daily oral iron supplementation on hematologic, growth, cognitive parameters, and adverse effects in exclusively breastfed infants.
results_summary: Iron supplementation showed no significant effect on iron deficiency or anemia but improved psychomotor development and mean corpuscular volume. It was associated with slower growth during exclusive breastfeeding, though long-term effects remain unclear.
population_specificity: Full-term healthy exclusively breastfed infants.

study_goal: To compare serum vitamin D levels in exclusively breastfed infants at 6 months of age with or without oral supplementation of 600,000 IU of vitamin D3 to mothers in the early postpartum period.
results_summary: Infants of mothers supplemented with vitamin D3 had significantly higher serum 25OHD levels at 6 months compared to controls, with no adverse effects observed. However, radiological rickets occurred in four infants (two in each group), while biochemical rickets was only seen in the control group.
population_specificity: Exclusively breastfeeding term parturient mothers and their infants.
effective_dosage: 60,000 IU/day of vitamin D3 for 10 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the nutrition-related structure, assumptions, and outputs of the Lives Saved Tool (LiST), including breastfeeding promotion and its impact on maternal and child health outcomes.
results_summary: The study highlights that breastfeeding promotion is included in LiST as an efficacious intervention linked to improved neonatal and child health outcomes, such as reduced mortality and improved nutrition status. The model incorporates evidence supporting breastfeeding's role in addressing stunting, wasting, and maternal anemia.
population_specificity: Maternal and child populations, particularly in low-resource settings where under-5 mortality and malnutrition are prevalent.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of prepregnancy obesity on self-reported delayed lactogenesis II and its association with early breastfeeding cessation.
results_summary: The study found that prepregnancy obesity and excessive gestational weight gain are associated with an increased risk of delayed lactogenesis II, which may lead to early breastfeeding cessation. Women with a BMI ≥ 30 kg/m² had a higher prevalence of delayed lactogenesis II compared to those with a BMI < 30 kg/m².
population_specificity: 216 women with a singleton pregnancy who planned to breastfeed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the risks and benefits of fluid supplementation (including breastfeeding) compared to standard fluid management in term and preterm newborn infants with unconjugated hyperbilirubinaemia requiring phototherapy.
results_summary: The study found no significant adverse effects from fluid supplementation, including breastfeeding, and no differences in breastfeeding frequencies between supplemented and non-supplemented infants. Serum bilirubin levels varied at some time points but showed no long-term clinical significance.
population_specificity: Term and preterm newborn infants with unconjugated hyperbilirubinaemia requiring phototherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine variation in formula supplementation among breastfed infants across hospitals, adjusting for socioeconomic, maternal, and infant factors, and to identify disparities and exemplar hospitals.
results_summary: Formula supplementation varied widely among hospitals (2.3% to 98.3%), with lower rates in level 1 hospitals. Significant disparities were noted for race, ethnicity, maternal education, and insurance coverage, while factors like smoking, cesarean delivery, and diabetes increased supplementation. Exemplar hospitals met the HealthyPeople 2020 goal of ≤14.2% supplementation.
population_specificity: 160,911 breastfed infants born in 126 New York hospitals in 2014.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of exogenous oxytocin administration during birth on breastfeeding outcomes in humans.
results_summary: Fifty percent of the measures showed an association between exogenous oxytocin and less optimal breastfeeding outcomes, 23% reported no association, and 26% had mixed findings. Breastfeeding intentions, parity, and birth setting were inconsistently controlled across studies.
population_specificity: Women who received exogenous oxytocin during the birth process, including both low-risk and higher-risk births.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of vitamin D supplementation in breastfeeding women for the prevention of allergic diseases.
results_summary: The study found very low certainty evidence suggesting vitamin D supplementation in breastfeeding women may not decrease the risk of developing asthma and/or wheezing. No significant effects were observed for other allergic diseases.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, breastfeeding women, infants, and children (though no studies were found for children).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of nutrition, including breastfeeding-promotion, in child growth and development.
results_summary: The study discusses the effects of breastfeeding-promotion as part of broader nutritional interventions, highlighting its role in improving child growth and development, though specific results for breastfeeding alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Mothers and children at high-risk of micronutrient deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if DHA supplementation during pregnancy in obese mothers reduces offspring adiposity.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in maternal erythrocyte DHA levels at 36 weeks gestation in the supplemented group, but the abstract does not provide conclusive results on offspring adiposity reduction.
population_specificity: Mothers with gestational diabetes or obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying transient neonatal zinc deficiency (TNZD) caused by SLC30A2/ZnT2 gene mutations and propose early diagnostic approaches to prevent TNZD morbidity.
results_summary: The study found that zinc-deficient breast milk due to SLC30A2/ZnT2 mutations leads to severe zinc deficiency in infants, with symptoms like dermatitis and diarrhea, but zinc supplementation effectively resolves these symptoms. The authors highlight the importance of early genetic diagnosis to prevent TNZD morbidity.
population_specificity: Infants exclusively breastfed by mothers with SLC30A2/ZnT2 gene mutations, particularly in American lactating mothers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a predominantly donor breastmilk (DBM) diet on growth and neurodevelopment in preterm infants compared to mother's own milk (MOM) or preterm formula (PF).
results_summary: Preterm infants fed predominantly DBM regained birthweight more slowly initially and scored lower in cognitive assessments at 1 and 2 years compared to those fed MOM or PF, though growth differences diminished over time.
population_specificity: Preterm infants in a level 3 neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) with a mean gestational age of 27.1 weeks and mean birthweight of 914 g.
effective_dosage: Predominantly (>50%) DBM, MOM, or PF supplementation.
study_duration: First month of life for growth assessment; neurodevelopment assessed at 1 and 2 years' corrected age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between maternal BMI and serum 25(OH)D levels and bone density in exclusively breastfeeding mother-infant pairs.
results_summary: Obese breastfeeding women had lower 25(OH)D concentrations and higher bone mineral density (BMD) than lean women at 1, 4, and 7 months postpartum. Higher maternal BMI was associated with lower maternal and infant serum 25(OH)D levels, potentially affecting infant bone density.
population_specificity: 234 exclusively breastfeeding mother-infant dyads recruited in the first postpartum month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single dose of maternal vitamin E supplementation could improve the vitamin E status of breastfeeding women in the first 60 days postpartum.
results_summary: The study found that a single 400 IU dose of RRR-α-tocopherol did not significantly change the mean serum α-tocopherol levels in breastfeeding women, indicating no improvement in vitamin E status. Both groups had inadequate dietary vitamin E intake, but their serum levels remained adequate throughout the study.
population_specificity: Fifty healthy breastfeeding women from two maternity hospitals in Natal, RN, Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if bone loss occurs in breastfeeding mothers, whether it is site-specific, and if correlations exist between serum bone turnover markers.
results_summary: Bone loss in exclusive breastfeeding mothers was site-specific, occurring in the lumbar bone at mid-lactation and the femoral bone in late lactation. Serum ionized calcium levels were lower in late lactation, and P1NP correlated with femoral BMD.
population_specificity: Exclusive breastfeeding mothers (1-6 months postpartum) compared to nonpregnant, nonlactating control women.
study_duration: 6 months (early, mid-, and late lactation phases)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of combined preventive nutrition interventions, including breastfeeding promotion, on improving linear growth (length-for-age z-scores) in children by 24 months.
results_summary: The study compared different combinations of interventions, including breastfeeding promotion, and found that bundled approaches could potentially mitigate childhood stunting, though specific results on breastfeeding alone were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their resultant children in a rural district of Bangladesh.
study_duration: Data collection spanned from pregnancy to 24 months postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of maternal nutritional supplementation combined with a breastfeeding support program on birth outcomes and breastfeeding performance.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased exclusive breastfeeding rates, improved infant breast milk intake (especially in mothers with lower baseline MUAC), and enhanced birth outcomes such as weight, weight-for-age, and head circumference-for-age.
population_specificity: 228 singleton Vietnamese mothers aged 20-35 years at 26-29 weeks of gestation with pre-pregnancy BMI < 25.0 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe early breastfeeding behaviors and perceived problems among first-time mothers intending to exclusively breastfeed.
results_summary: The study found that 38% of women used formula during hospitalization, and 68% used formula by 2 weeks, with breastfeeding problems peaking at Week 2. Women with in-hospital formula use or less positive baseline attitudes were less likely to exclusively breastfeed at 2 and 8 weeks.
population_specificity: Primiparous, primarily highly educated, White women committed to breastfeeding.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how omega-3 PUFA supplementation in breastfeeding mothers affects the fatty acid composition of human milk, particularly alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) levels and the LA-ALA ratio.
results_summary: Omega-3 supplementation significantly increased ALA content in human milk, with the highest levels observed in the group receiving both enriched margarine and rapeseed oil (MR). The MR group also showed the most favorable LA-ALA ratio for LC-PUFA synthesis, while docosahexaenoic acid and trans FA concentrations remained unchanged across groups.
population_specificity: Breastfeeding women (19-22 per group) in a multicenter study.
effective_dosage: Not specified (supplementation via enriched margarine, rapeseed oil, or a combination for 15 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short and long-term respiratory health effects of breastfeeding and maternal dietary patterns during the first 1000 days from conception.
results_summary: Breastfeeding has beneficial effects on respiratory infections, but its protective effect on allergic disorders remains unclear. The study found no evidence to avoid or encourage highly allergenic foods during complementary feeding to modify tolerance development.
population_specificity: Children from birth to two years and their mothers (during pregnancy and lactation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of lipid-based nutrient supplement (LNS) versus corn-soy blend (CSB), different soy qualities, and varying milk protein percentages in promoting fat-free tissue accretion in children with moderate acute malnutrition (MAM).
results_summary: The study found that LNS resulted in greater fat-free mass index (FFMI) accretion compared to CSB, while soy isolate (SI) showed no significant advantage over dehulled soy (DS). A 20% milk protein inclusion trended toward improved FFMI but was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 6- to 23-month-old children with moderate acute malnutrition in Burkina Faso, 95% of whom were breastfed.
effective_dosage: 500 kcal/day as LNS or CSB, containing SI or DS, with 0%, 20%, or 50% of protein from milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of early parenteral iron supplementation combined with erythropoietin on preventing anemia in preterm infants, including its impact on breastfeeding outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in breastfeeding cases among the groups. Early parenteral iron supplementation combined with erythropoietin improved reticulocyte percentages, reduced total iron binding capacity, and enhanced hemoglobin and mean cell volume levels at 3 months.
population_specificity: Preterm infants
study_duration: 2 weeks of life, with follow-up at corrected ages of 1 and 3 months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of breastfeeding on neuropsychological benefits in children, as part of a broader study on environmental and nutritional factors affecting child development.
results_summary: The study found that breastfeeding contributes to neuropsychological benefits in children, alongside other factors like balanced maternal fish intake and prenatal exposure to certain pollutants. It highlighted the importance of breastfeeding as part of a comprehensive approach to child development.
population_specificity: Spanish children from the INMA birth cohort (over 3,500 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if supplementing human milk with calcium and phosphorus improves growth and bone metabolism in preterm infants without significant adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of differences in growth outcomes (weight, length, head circumference) between supplemented and non-supplemented groups. Supplementation reduced serum alkaline phosphatase levels at six weeks, but this was unlikely to be clinically significant.
population_specificity: Hospitalized preterm infants.
study_duration: Outcomes measured at two, four, and six weeks postnatal age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between mastitis and antiretroviral therapy (ART) among HIV-positive, breastfeeding women, comparing maternal ART, infant nevirapine (NVP), and standard of care.
results_summary: The study found that both maternal ART and infant NVP were associated with a higher risk of mastitis or breast inflammation compared to standard of care, with increased hazard ratios for late-appearing mastitis. The findings suggest that mastitis may be a side effect of prophylactic ART or infant NVP during breastfeeding.
population_specificity: HIV-positive, breastfeeding women in Lilongwe, Malawi, who delivered live infants between 2004 and 2007.
study_duration: 24 weeks of exclusive breastfeeding and 4 weeks of weaning (28 weeks total).
interactions: Maternal ART and infant NVP were associated with increased risk of mastitis or breast inflammation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D3 supplementation (1,800 IU/d) in lactating mothers improves their vitamin D status and breast milk vitamin D levels.
results_summary: Vitamin D3 supplementation significantly increased maternal 25(OH)D levels but did not significantly increase breast milk 25(OH)D levels, though the change in milk levels was significantly different from the placebo group.
population_specificity: Thai lactating mothers with 25(OH)D levels of 10-30 ng/ml and their breast-fed infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish recommendations for complementary feeding (CF) in healthy term infants in Europe, emphasizing the role and duration of breastfeeding.
results_summary: The study recommends exclusive or full breastfeeding for at least 4 months and predominant breastfeeding for about 6 months, with complementary foods introduced between 4-6 months. It highlights the importance of varied flavors, iron-rich foods, and avoiding added sugar/salt, while noting specific guidelines for allergenic foods and vegan diets.
population_specificity: Healthy term infants in Europe.
effective_dosage: Not specified (focus on duration and types of foods).
study_duration: Up to 12 months (for certain dietary introductions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and perceived benefits of a galega-based food supplement in supporting breastfeeding mothers and enhancing milk production.
results_summary: The majority of mothers reported satisfaction with the product, with two-thirds noting improved milk production. The supplement was also associated with perceived psychological benefits and a high level of safety.
population_specificity: Italian breastfeeding mothers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the safety of creatine monohydrate and other creatine forms, with special focus on vulnerable subgroups, excluding pregnant and breastfeeding women.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about breastfeeding, only noting that breastfeeding women were excluded from safety evaluations. Limited safety data exist for some creatine forms, with concerns raised for creatine orotate, creatine phosphate, and magnesium creatine chelate.
population_specificity: Healthy adults, excluding pregnant and breastfeeding women.
effective_dosage: 3 g per day (for general creatine intake).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether providing small-quantity lipid-based nutrient supplements (SQ-LNS) impacts breastfeeding or complementary feeding practices in infants.
results_summary: The study found that SQ-LNS did not negatively affect breastfeeding practices and may have improved feeding frequency in two sites (Burkina Faso and Malawi). Dietary diversity indicators mostly remained unchanged, though SQ-LNS was associated with higher consumption of animal-source foods in those same sites.
population_specificity: Infants aged 18 months from diverse sites in Africa (Ghana, Burkina Faso, Malawi, and one unspecified site).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of calcium supplementation in ensuring bone health among adults aged ≥65 years.
results_summary: The study suggests that calcium, along with vitamin D, is beneficial for bone health in older adults, though the abstract does not provide specific outcome data. The broader context indicates that supplementation can help meet nutritional requirements in at-risk populations.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥65 years
